heroIntro:
Welcome to your peaceful retirement haven in Lomas de Campoamor, Orihuela Costa. This exceptional 2-bedroom, 2-bathroom apartment offers the relaxed lifestyle you've been searching for, with year-round Mediterranean sunshine and a welcoming international expat community. Priced at €238,000, this property represents outstanding value—featuring premium specifications at 35% less than comparable properties on Costa Blanca North.

Located in one of Alicante's most sought-after coastal communities, this home combines modern comfort with the easy-going pace of life that makes retirement in Spain so appealing. With 109 square meters of thoughtfully designed living space, you'll enjoy everything from morning coffee on your terrace to evening strolls through tree-lined neighborhoods. The strong British, Scandinavian, and Dutch expat communities here mean you'll never feel isolated, while superb healthcare facilities and English-speaking medical professionals ensure your peace of mind.

Orihuela Costa has earned its reputation as a premier retirement destination. Unlike the hustle of Costa Blanca North, this area offers authentic Spanish coastal living at genuinely affordable prices. Your €238,000 investment secures not just a property, but access to championship golf courses, pristine beaches, excellent shopping, and a lifestyle that balances activity with relaxation—exactly what the most discerning retirees are seeking.
areaSection: Orihuela Costa stretches along the southern reaches of Alicante's coastline, offering a distinctly different character from the busier northern regions. This area encompasses charming villages and residential communities like Lomas de Campoamor, each with its own personality while sharing the region's hallmarks: abundant sunshine (320+ days yearly), Mediterranean breezes, and crystalline waters. The terrain gently slopes toward the coast, creating natural neighborhoods with excellent views and drainage. The Costa Blanca's southern portion benefits from a slightly warmer microclimate, perfect for those seeking genuine warmth without excessive summer heat. Orihuela Costa has evolved into a mature, established community where infrastructure is well-developed and proven. Unlike newer speculative developments, this area has weathered decades of real estate cycles, demonstrating genuine long-term appeal to residents and investors alike.
lifestyleSection: Daily life in Orihuela Costa revolves around leisure, community, and easy access to Spain's coastal pleasures. Your mornings might begin at a local café with café con leche and toast, chatting with fellow residents from across Europe. Shopping is stress-free—Mercadona, Consum, and Lidl are minutes away, supplemented by weekly village markets offering fresh produce. Healthcare is excellent: you're minutes from Hospital de Torrevieja and Quirónsalud, both equipped with English-speaking staff accustomed to international patients. The expat infrastructure here is mature and well-organized—book clubs, golf groups, beach walks, and cultural activities mean social life happens naturally. Beaches like La Zenia and Campoamor offer Blue Flag status and calm waters perfect for gentle swimming. Dining ranges from authentic Spanish chiringuitos (beach bars) to international restaurants catering to cosmopolitan tastes. The pace is distinctly relaxed—nobody rushes here—yet opportunity for activity is everywhere, from championship golf courses to yoga classes to coastal hiking trails.
investmentSection: Beyond being an excellent personal residence, this property represents sound financial judgment. Orihuela Costa properties have appreciated 10% year-on-year, outpacing inflation and creating genuine wealth building. At €238,000 (€2,183/m²), you're positioned just 4% above the area's €2,100/m² average—excellent value given the property's condition and location. Should you ever wish to rent it out, comparable apartments generate €800 per week in peak season, suggesting annual rental income potential of €30,000-€35,000 if you choose that route. The area's established international community ensures consistent rental demand. Most importantly, you're acquiring property at 35% less per square meter than Costa Blanca North developments, yet with equal or superior amenities and climate. This pricing differential reflects location preference, not quality—savvy investors have recognized Orihuela Costa's value for over two decades.
conclusion:
This exceptional 2-bedroom apartment in Lomas de Campoamor represents far more than a property purchase—it's an invitation to the relaxed Mediterranean retirement lifestyle you've earned. At €238,000 with premium specifications at 35% less than comparable Costa Blanca North properties, the financial logic is compelling. The established expat community, excellent healthcare, year-round sunshine, and authentic coastal living create the setting for genuinely fulfilling retirement.

Orihuela Costa has weathered 40+ years of real estate cycles and demographic changes, proving its genuine long-term appeal to serious retirees. lifeAndAmenities.intro: Orihuela Costa has matured into a fully-equipped community where daily conveniences require no compromise. Everything from fresh groceries to medical care to entertainment is minutes away, allowing you to focus on enjoying retirement rather than managing logistics.

healthcare.text: Healthcare in Orihuela Costa exceeds expectations for a coastal community. Hospital de Torrevieja, just 15 minutes away, is one of Spain's finest private hospitals with full emergency services, English-speaking physicians, and specialists across every discipline. Quirónsalud in nearby Torrevieja provides additional options. Local medical centers staffed with English-speaking doctors handle routine care, prescriptions, and check-ups without the language barriers you might fear. Many physicians trained internationally and cater specifically to the large expat population. Spanish public healthcare (covered under reciprocal EU agreements for UK retirees with proper registration) is also accessible, offering an economical alternative. Pharmaceutical costs remain significantly lower than UK or Scandinavian prices. The region has excellent ambulance services and air ambulance access for complex emergencies.
keyPoints: Hospital de Torrevieja: 15 minutes, full private medical facilities with English-speaking staff
Quirónsalud: 20 minutes, alternative private hospital with emergency services
Local medical centers: 2-5 minutes, English-speaking doctors for routine care

education.text: While you're retiring rather than raising children, quality schools matter if you're hosting grandchildren or considering relocation with younger family members. El Limonar International School (15 minutes away) offers British curriculum education for ages 3-18, with excellent facilities and international student body. Kings College Murcia, 40 minutes distant, provides another respected British education option. Both schools welcome short-term attendance for visiting grandchildren. The local Spanish schools in Orihuela Costa are well-regarded and significantly less expensive if you prefer integration into the Spanish system. English-language instruction is increasingly available at public institutions serving the international community.

shopping.text: Shopping in Orihuela Costa caters to every budget and preference. Mercadona and Consum supermarkets (3-5 minutes) stock everything from Spanish staples to international brands—German products, UK foods, Scandinavian items. Lidl provides budget-conscious alternatives. La Zenia Boulevard, Spain's largest outlet and shopping mall complex (10 minutes), offers 150+ shops ranging from Zara to Carrefour to local boutiques. Weekly outdoor markets in Orihuela Town (10 minutes) deliver fresh produce, fish, and local products at remarkable prices. Specialized shops for English newspapers, Nordic foods, and imported goods serve the expat community. Online shopping with next-day delivery through Amazon.es is also increasingly prevalent.

La Zenia Boulevard: 10 minutes, 150+ shops and Spain's largest outlet mall

transport.text: A car is essential in Orihuela Costa—public buses exist but run infrequently and serve limited routes. However, driving here is remarkably pleasant: roads are well-maintained, traffic outside summer peaks is light, and distances are manageable. Alicante-Elche Airport (50 minutes) is Spain's third-busiest, offering abundant flight options to the UK, Scandinavia, Netherlands, and rest of Europe. Parking in residential areas is typically free. Torrevieja Port (20 minutes) serves as an alternative transport hub. Within the community, electric bikes or golf buggies serve for very short journeys. Winter fuel costs are negligible compared to northern heating bills.

faqs.question: Is Orihuela Costa a good place to live?
faqs.answer: Yes, Orihuela Costa is excellent for retirees seeking relaxed Mediterranean living. The area combines mature infrastructure with authentic Spanish character, avoiding the overdevelopment of Costa Blanca North. Strong expat communities ensure you're never isolated, healthcare rivals UK standards, and costs run 30-40% below Northern Europe. Most residents stay decades, testimony to genuine satisfaction.

faqs.question: What is Orihuela Costa known for?
faqs.answer: Orihuela Costa is known as Spain's premier established resort community, famous for championship golf courses (Villamartín, Campoamor, Las Ramblas), pristine Blue Flag beaches, strong international expat communities, and genuine affordability. Unlike newer developments, it's proven its long-term appeal over 40+ years, attracting retirees seeking stability and authenticity.

faqs.question: Is Orihuela Costa safe?
faqs.answer: Yes. Orihuela Costa has lower crime rates than most European coastal towns. The established expat community watches out for neighbors, properties are typically well-maintained with secure developments, and police presence is visible. Serious crimes are exceptionally rare. Like any coastal area, standard urban precautions (not flashing valuables, parking in well-lit areas) apply.

faqs.question: How far is Orihuela Costa from Alicante?
faqs.answer: Approximately 60 kilometers south of Alicante city center, requiring 50 minutes by car to Alicante-Elche Airport. The distance is advantageous—you gain authentic coastal living without city noise and congestion. Direct bus services exist for airport transfers, and Torrevieja (20 minutes) offers alternative transport options.

faqs.question: What's the rental income potential for this apartment?
faqs.answer: €800 per week during peak season is typical for comparable 2-bedroom apartments in Lomas de Campoamor, suggesting €30,000-€35,000 annual income if you choose to rent. Off-season rates are lower (€500-€600/week). The established international clientele ensures steady demand. Many owners rent June-September then enjoy their homes the remainder of the year.

faqs.question: Do I need a car in Lomas de Campoamor?
faqs.answer: Yes, a car is essential. While the neighborhood is walkable for daily needs (supermarkets, restaurants), accessing beaches, golf courses, airport, and larger amenities requires driving. However, roads are excellent, traffic outside summer peaks is light, and parking is typically free. Many retirees find driving here genuinely pleasant compared to congested Northern Europe.

faqs.question: What healthcare options exist for British retirees?
faqs.answer: Excellent options. Hospital de Torrevieja (15 minutes) is Spain's finest private facility with full emergency services and English-speaking physicians. Quirónsalud (20 minutes) provides alternatives. Local medical centers handle routine care affordably. UK retirees with proper registration access Spanish public healthcare through reciprocal EU agreements. Costs run 60% below UK private hospital fees.

faqs.question: Can I get a mortgage as a retiree?
faqs.answer: Yes. Spanish banks increasingly offer mortgages to EU retirees with pension income, typically covering 70-80% of purchase price at attractive rates (currently 3-4%). Notably, you can obtain UK pensions in Spanish banks for mortgage qualification. Most retirees can qualify if their pension income exceeds €1,200/month and they're under 75.

faqs.question: What are community fees for this apartment?
faqs.answer: Specific fees for this property are modest—typically €40-60/month for Lomas de Campoamor community maintenance. These cover common area upkeep, gardening, community insurance, and management. Spanish property taxes (IBI) are approximately €200-300 annually. Combined ongoing costs remain remarkably low compared to Northern Europe, leaving maximum income for living enjoyment.
